I am a postdoctoral fellow at Jameel Poverty Action Lab's King Climate Action Initiative at MIT and a visiting scholar at UCSD's Global Policy School. My research lies at the intersection of environmental and resource economics, development economics, and political economy. In particular, my research is structured around three key themes: (1) collective action and community cooperation for managing shared resources, (2) the adoption of sustainable technologies to enhance agricultural returns, and (3) the pivotal role of information in motivating behavioral and policy changes.
job market paper  studies whether the standard tragedy of the commons problem for groundwater is exacerbated by administrative jurisdictions in India. Specifically, we find that when districts overlap competitively with a groundwater resource, they promote water-intensive agricultural practices through their budgetary allocations to policy. My advisors at Harvard include Professors Rema Hanna (Chair), Emily Breza, Melissa Dell, along with Tavneet Suri at the Sloan School of Management (MIT).--Before starting my postdoc, I got my Ph.D. in Public Policy (Economics Track) at Harvard university. I received my MA in International and Development Economics at Yale University and have a BA in Economics and Statistics from St. Xavier’s College, Mumbai.
